item.title: Kerry Focuses on Iran, North Korea Leaders
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry, in his campaign to stabilize North Asia and the Middle East, is wrestling to understand the strategic calculations of two distinctly different—yet obscure and ruthless—men.

item.title: Second Bird Flu Case Found in Beijing
item.description: Chinese authorities said a boy in the Chinese capital of Beijing had tested positive for a deadly new form of avian flu, in the second reported case of a child contracting the flu in the northern city.

item.title: Venezuela Says Chávez Successor Wins Vote
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, a one-time bus driver who went on to become a confidant of late President Hugo Chávez, won a razor-thin victory in Venezuela's presidential elections.

item.title: Greece on Track for Next Aid Tranche
item.description: Greece is on track to meet the conditions of its international bailout, paving the way for the payment of a fresh slice of financial aid, international lenders said.

item.title: China GDP Growth Slows to 7.7%
item.description: China's economic growth slowed unexpectedly in the first quarter, raising concerns that a recovery that started in the second half of last year is already losing steam.

item.title: Afghan Opium Production Surges
item.description: The amount of land under opium cultivation in Afghanistan increased for a third straight year, a United Nations survey released on Monday said.

item.title: Sweden to Boost Election-Year Spending
item.description: Sweden plans to boost government spending in the 2014 election year to keep in check unemployment fueled by sluggish economic growth and weak demand for the nation's exports to the rest of Europe.

item.title: Centrica, Qatar Petroleum Buy Suncor Assets
item.description: Centrica and state-owned Qatar Petroleum said they have reached an agreement with Suncor Energy to buy a vast chunk of its natural gas and crude oil business in Canada for almost $1 billion.

item.title: Palestinian Shake-Up Roils Peace Bid
item.description: Palestinian Prime Minister Salam Fayyad's resignation removes a trusted Washington ally from power and threatens to roil Palestinian politics just as the Obama administration ramps up a new peace push.

item.title: Gunmen Attack Somali Court
item.description: Al--Shabab Islamic extremists stormed Somalia's main court complex while the Supreme Court was in session, firing a barrage of bullets during a gun battle with security forces that lasted two hours, officials said.

item.title: Afghanistan Protests New Border Gate
item.description: In the latest irritant to Kabul's relations with Pakistan, Afghan President Hamid Karzai orders top security officials to remove a new Pakistani border gate.

item.title: Russia Bans Americans in Reprisal
item.description: Russia banned 18 Americans from entering its territory, responding to a list by the Obama administration that barred the same number of Russians from the U.S. for alleged involvement in a death .

item.title: Lion Air Pilots Pass Initial Drug Test
item.description: The pilot and co-pilot of the Lion Air passenger plane that crashed in Bali on Saturday passed their initial drug test, as investigators continued their search for the accident's cause.

item.title: Vigilance Increases as Bird Flu Spreads
item.description: A deadly new strain of avian flu has spread to new parts of China, sparking worries that the disease could be difficult to keep from spreading to other places—including neighboring countries.

item.title: Egypt to Spend on Refineries
item.description: Cash-strapped Egypt will spend $18 billion until 2017 to build new refineries and modify existing plants in a move to increase its annual fuel output, the country's oil minister said in an interview with Al Tahrir Television.

item.title: Korea Trade Pact Gains Mixed
item.description: The Obama administration is touting the year-old free-trade deal between the U.S. and South Korea as proof that such pacts boost exports. But the message is clouded by mixed trade data and complaints.

item.title: Greeks See Ray of Hope in Tourist Bookings
item.description: Greece's tourism industry is counting on a million more visitors this year, something that would provide a welcome boost to the economy.

item.title: Pope Begins Vatican Overhaul
item.description: Pope Francis appointed a panel of cardinals to advise on overhauling the Vatican administration, the opening salvo of a papacy that many expect to introduce sweeping reforms.

item.title: Birth Rates as Growth Engines
item.description: The Outlook: Long a laggard among developing countries, the Philippines is finally showing progress in its bid to harness the economic potential of its youthful and growing population.

item.title: China Hotel Fire Kills 11
item.description: Eleven people have been killed and 50 others injured in a fire in central China that spread to a hotel.

item.title: Indian Parties' Spat Over Modi Escalates
item.description: India's Bharatiya Janata Party on Sunday rejected aspersions cast by ally Janata Dal (United) on party leader and Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi's role in the deadly 2002 riots, sharply escalating tensions between the two long-standing allies.

item.title: Inside Congo's Link in the Gold Chain
item.description: Gold smuggled out of the Democratic Republic of Congo is finding its way to the markets of Dubai and jewelry shops around the world.

item.title: Merkel Rivals Struggle to Find Foothold
item.description: Angela Merkel's opponents have been trying to knock her from power in September's election. With the vote five months away, the opposition is in a quandary.

item.title: India Court Finds Man Guilty for Pune Blast
item.description: A court in Pune found a man guilty for his role in a bomb blast at a popular café in the western Indian city three years ago, the first conviction for an attack that killed 17 people and injured more than 60 others.

item.title: In Venezuela, Almost-Free Gas Comes at a High Cost
item.description: The winner of Sunday's vote to succeed the late Hugo Chávez as Venezuelan president faces economic distortions caused by policies such as one that freezes gasoline's price at just a few cents a gallon.

item.title: The Roots of Heaven
item.description: Still relatively remote, Jamaica's Port Antonio retains the same sleepy, fishing town vibe that first lured Hollywood and jet-set royalty in the 1950s. On its jungle-wrapped beaches, you won't worry about a thing.

item.title: Pioneer of In-Vitro Fertilization Dies
item.description: Robert Edwards, a feisty British embryologist who fundamentally transformed human procreation by developing in vitro fertilization, died at age 87.

item.title: For Swatch, It's Time for a Change
item.description: For years, Swatch supplied its fellow Swiss watchmakers with mechanisms, balance springs and other parts found in mechanical timepieces. The company is now pushing to reduce its supplies, which could trigger a big restructuring of the Swiss watch industry.

item.title: Photos of the Day: April 14
item.description: In today's pictures, a Buchenwald survivor remembers in Germany, deadly attacks strike Somalia, marathoners compete in North Korea, and more.

item.title: Photos of the Week: April 7-13
item.description: In this week's photos, a man fishes on a lake in India, a woman watches men pray from behind a screen at the Western Wall in Jerusalem, a customer examines a pigeon at a market in China, and more.

item.title: A Trudeau Follows in Pierre's Dance Steps
item.description: Justin Trudeau, the 41-year-old son of legendary Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau has captured attention in a flashy campaign to win leadership of the opposition Liberal party.

item.title: A Cloud Looms Over China
item.description: In the wake of soaring air-pollution readings in Beijing, many expatriate workers are choosing to leave China due to the health risks.

item.title: Marathon of the Sands
item.description: The deserts of Morocco this week are crawling with athletes competing in the 28th Marathon des Sables, a multiday footrace through the Sahara.
